Column The Silver Shield: Johnny Gaudreau defied tall odds to reach NHL stardom

The 11-year NHL vet was tragically killed Thursday night, shocking fans, teammates and family members.

From college to the NHL, Johnny Gaudreau was well known on the ice as Johnny Hockey. (Photo courtesy of Wikimedia Commons / Union College)

By Kasey Kazliner August 31, 2024 at  4:09 pm PDT

“The Silver Shield” is a column by Kasey Kazliner about the National Hockey League.

Johnny and Matthew Gaudreau’s lives should have never been taken away. The brothers were biking in Salem County, New Jersey, on Thursday night, when a drunk driver struck them both, killing them on the eve of their sister’s wedding. Johnny was 31 years old and Matthew was 29.

Matthew spent the bulk of his hockey career in the minors while “Johnny Hockey” led a storied one — battling doubt and adversity — with the Calgary Flames and Columbus Blue Jackets after playing collegiately at Boston College, where he earned the Johnny Manziel-inspired nickname.

Johnny’s draft journey was incredible. Originally overlooked because of his 5-foot-6, 137-pound frame, The elder Gaudreau’s first mission was to prove the scoffing scouts wrong. Calgary took a chance on the smallest player in the 2011 draft, picking Gaudreau with the No. 104 selection. But at 17 years old and still a boy among men, he would have to earn his NHL status.

Gaudreau grabbed attention by winning the 2011 USHL title with the Dubuque Fighting Saints before joining Boston College. Gaudreau would soon etch his name in BC history by not only helping the Eagles win a national title in 2012 as a newcomer, but averaging a whopping two points per game just two seasons later to take home the 2014 Hobey Baker award as the top college hockey player.

The Flames didn’t take long to notice his impact and offered Gaudreau his contract the same day he accepted the Hobey Baker. The rest is history.

While Gaudreau’s Flames never received deep-playoff glory, the hard-nosed, dazzling left wing made a name for himself with multiple point-per-game seasons and highlight-level offensive production. Gaudreau’s final season with Calgary in 2021-22 put other teams on notice, as the then-28-year-old notched 115 points with 40 goals and 75 assists. His point total only trailed Oilers forward Connor McDavid, confirming Gaudreau’s legitimacy as a scoring forward in the league.

Gaudreau would look to build off his success, potentially with a new team, as he became a free agent following the Flames’ second-round playoff loss. To the dismay of Flames fans, Gaudreau chose Columbus as his new home in free agency. His time in Ohio only spanned two seasons and it was primarily during a transition phase for the Blue Jackets, but he was expected to be a mentor for young, up-and-coming players like 2023 No. 3 overall pick Adam Fantilli.

Gaudreau joined a historically unsuccessful Columbus bunch hoping to help change the culture. While he won’t be around to continue his leadership on the ice, the Blue Jackets will carry his torch and play in honor of Johnny Hockey.

A seven-time All-Star, Gaudreau proved his worth despite falling far on draft night. His combination of an infectious spirit, cerebral playmaking and shiftiness made him a unique talent with the ability to impact games and get the crowd on its feet.

Gaudreau will be remembered as a player who gave it all on the ice. As a shorter player, he was scrappy, creating chances in occasionally unconventional ways. And he won’t be forgotten, not just as a hockey player. Gaudreau was a father, husband and a friend to many. His tragic story will be mourned by supporters across all 32 fanbases, remembering his impact and passion.

Talent comes in all shapes and sizes, even in a league dominated by physicality. At 5-foot-9, Gaudreau wasn’t afraid of anyone. He embraced the challenge and made competition interesting.

May Johnny and Matthew rest in peace.

Maribel ‘Mary’ Flores will represent Mexico at U-20 Women’s World Cup

University of Southern California’s striker will help lead attack for El Tri

Freshman forward Maribel Flores notched the only USC goal during an 0-1-1 trip to the desert. (Photo by Wesley Chen)

By Michelle Chavez August 31, 2024 at 11:56 am PDT

On Saturday, Trojan fans will see a familiar face at the 2024 Women’s U-20 World Cup in Colombia with Mexico’s women’s national team. Rising sophomore Maribel “Mary” Flores will be among the 25 players called to represent La Selección at the event.

The USC forward will help lead Mexico’s attack against Cameroon in the first match of the group stage on August 31. Flores trained with the team until August 19 before heading to Colombia for the tournament. The rising star is no stranger to major tournaments, having worn the Mexico team jersey on the international stage before. Flores previously helped the squad to a U20 CONCACAF Championship in 2023. She also represented El Tri at the 2022 U17 World Cup and the 2022 U17 CONCACAF Tournament where she scored eight goals and had seven assists.

Flores has thrived as a Woman of Troy, netting six goals and five assists as the 2023 Pac-12 Freshman of the Year, earning All-American second team status and leading all freshmen in the conference for scoring. Her 17 total points placed her 11th overall in the league, and her contributions helped the team to the second round of the NCAA tournament, finishing third in the conference behind UCLA and Stanford. Her skills and determination will transfer from the Pac-12 to the Big Ten conference as USC makes the move for the upcoming season.

The California native from Fullerton made local news when she chose to decommit from Stanford, the school she originally signed with in 2021, to join USC for her freshman season as she continued participating with the Mexican national team. Although she has the skill set and talent to successfully play at the professional level, Flores chose to pursue a college career rather than a professional one straight out of high school.

“I have always had in the back of my head, what would it be like if I just went pro right now and didn’t finish school,” Flores said in a recent interview with The Daily Trojan. “But my family [and] everyone I talked to is like, ‘You have to finish school,’ and I think I’m starting to see the bigger picture now. So I will be finishing school because nobody can take away my education.”

With increasing support and attention towards women’s sports in recent years and the exponential success of the National Women’s Soccer League and La Liga MX Femenil, many young players are forgoing the traditional collegiate path and signing contracts with pro teams. Local NWSL club Angel City F.C. made headlines with record breaking signings of Alyssa Thompson, Gisele Thompson, Casey Phair and Kennedy Fuller who all joined prior to their high school graduations.

Flores will be one of four collegiate athletes on the U20 team, playing alongside three collegiate rivals from UCLA as they work to advance to the knockout stage and beyond. The rest of the squad is composed of players from Liga MX Femenil clubs including Pachuca, Atlas and Club América. Flores’s call up gives her the opportunity to showcase the skills she’s built both at USC and on the national level. Her selection is also part of a new shift in the Mexico national team-one that has begun to encompass more Mexican-American players.

The Los Angeles Dodgers won its three-game series against the Baltimore Orioles in what could be a future World Series matchup. LA’s offense and defense were both on fire, yet the Dodgers sneaked by one of the AL’s top squads. As Dodgers designated hitter Shohei Ohtani nears history as the first player to achieve 45 home runs and 45 steals in a season, the team became the first to reach the 80-win mark. Los Angeles has been on fire lately, winning 14 of their last 19 and mounting a four-game lead over the Arizona Diamondbacks and the San Diego Padres.

The Orioles were hot at the beginning of the season, but have since simmered. They’ve beaten the teams they’re supposed to, but struggle against the league’s big dogs. The series against the Dodgers was no different. Los Angeles put Jack Flaherty on the bump in Game 1, and he continued his streak of solid pitching with five strikeouts through six innings pitched. However, the Orioles managed to overcome Flaherty, and the Dodgers fell 3-2.

On Ohtani’s bobblehead night, it was fitting that he hit a 390-foot bomb in his opening at-bat in Game 2. The Dodgers took the lead in the third after a Teoscar Hernández home run and cruised to a 6-4 victory. Game 3 was much of the same. Los Angeles took advantage of a fatigued Orioles starter Cade Povich and jumped to a 5-0 lead by the end of the fourth inning. From there, the Dodgers’ bullpen was able to hold it down. LA reliever Blake Treinen struck out three out of four batters he faced, two of which looking. The Dodgers won the game 6-3, taking the series against a solid AL opponent.

LA is finding its groove at the perfect time. The rest of the season features a mix of opponents who are all across the league standings, giving LA time to rest their starters but also giving them enough of a challenge. The Dodgers’ upcoming series against the Diamondbacks could repeat itself in the first round of the playoffs. Arizona has been scorching hot after the All-Star break, going 27-10. They are now in a top wildcard spot and are not far behind the Dodgers for first in the NL West. Los Angeles is also scheduled to play another dominant NL West team in the San Diego Padres. The Padres are 26-11 since the All-Star break and have quickly become one of the top-hitting teams in the league. The matchup will be an end-of-season test for the Dodgers that will help them prepare for what they will see in October. LA will also play six games against the Colorado Rockies, one of the league’s worst teams. The mix of teams at the end of their schedule should allow the Dodgers to keep their momentum going while adequately preparing them for the matchups they will see this postseason.

Sparks stun Liberty in upset victory

Dearica Hamby led the Sparks with 21 points, but the team’s young players secured the win.

Sparks rookie guard Rickea Jackson (2) looks ahead against the New York Liberty. (Photo/Instagram @LA_Sparks)

By Mia Nuñez August 30, 2024 at 5:02 pm PDT

LOS ANGELES – Head coach Curt Miller believed that the Sparks’ key to success against the New York Liberty was having a fighting spirit in them, which they fully accomplished. The Sparks (7-24) were coming off of a seven-game losing streak including a disappointing loss to the Dallas Wings in which they blew a 19-point lead. Because of LA’s woes, the first-place Liberty (26-6) were the favorite to win on Wednesday. Defying the odds, the Sparks won 94-88.

At practice on Tuesday, Sparks rookie guard Rickea Jackson said that “Going after [the Liberty] and not being scared of a challenge” was an emphasis for the whole team. An emerging star, Jackson backed her word by scoring 15 points in the first half. The Sparks wanted to redeem themselves after a 35-point loss from their last head-to-head game against the Liberty.

“We turned them over on the first two possessions of the game and that really set the tone,” Miller said postgame. Those two turnovers piled into 20 total turnovers and were a leading factor in LA’s win. The Sparks scored 29 points off takeaways, giving them the edge against the Liberty for most of the game.

Jackson and forward Dearica Hamby combined for 40 points in the Sparks’ victory. But it wasn’t an easy effort for the Sparks because they lost their 9-point lead heading into the end of the fourth quarter. This wasn’t a new occurrence, as the Sparks have struggled with closing out games all season, including against Dallas, as LA lacked the fight that Miller mentioned, but showed it against the Liberty.

Jackson started the job and guard Rae Burell finished it. Burell sealed the deal for the Sparks in the fourth quarter when she scored 11 of her 18 points. She was locked in, shooting from the paint, beyond the arc and drawing fouls.

“I’m just happy that my team was able to put me in great positions to get those shots,” Burrell said humbly about her performance.

The Sparks have been able to beat some of the best teams in the WNBA like the Liberty and the Aces, but haven’t won a game against other struggling teams like the Mystics and Dream.

“Down the stretch, we emphasized that we’ve got to close this game,” Hamby said.”We’ve got to get stops.”

The Sparks’ future appears bright as they appear to be incrementally building chemistry. LA looks to keep up its momentum against the Atlanta Dream. In their last matchup, the Dream won 87-74, so the Sparks are seeking redemption and chasing their first win against them this season. Tipoff will be Sunday at 4 p.m. at Crypto.com Arena.

Giesler’s Grand Slam: Ohtani chasing history

The Kansas City Royals fight for first, Danny Jansen plays for two teams in one game and the double play going into the weekend.

Danny Jansen made baseball history this past weekend when he played for two teams in one game (Photo courtesy of the Boston Red Sox @redsox)

By Andrew Giesler August 30, 2024 at 7:45 am PDT

Ohtani seeks 45 home runs and 45 steals

Shohei Ohtani has already proven he can pitch and hit at an elite level, leading baseball fans to begin comparing him with the likes of Babe Ruth. One of the most underrated parts of his game, however, is his ability to steal bases, already tallying 42 on the year. Last month, Ohtani joined the 40-40 club and is showing no signs of slowing down. With 29 games remaining in the season, Ohtani will likely become the founding member of the 45-45 club. With 42 steals and 42 home runs, it is only a matter of time before he makes history and joins a club that’s literally his own.

Though Ohtani’s the easy choice for NL MVP, he’s only second in the league in both statistics. Aaron Judge of the New York Yankees has already hit 51 home runs and is likely going to reach the 60 mark for the second time in his career. Cincinnati Reds’ shortstop Elly De La Cruz leads the league in steals with 61, which is especially impressive given that his batting is right at the league’s average.

The Kansas City Royals are back after a long down period

The Kansas City Royals have not been the same since their World Series victory in 2015, but the squad has a chance to change things this year. The difference for the Royals has been their hitting, with shortstop Bobby Witt leading the way. They are in the top six for hits, runs and batting average, which has made up for any lapses on the mound. The team is solid on the bump, with Seth Lugo and Cole Ragans holding it down as the teams’ ace starters. Despite giving up greater-than-average hits, the team can lock in defensively, giving up the eighth-least amount of runs. They also give up the second least amount of homers, allowing them to stay in games.

The Royals are now only one game back from the Cleveland Guardians in the AL Central division. If Kansas City finds a way to surpass Cleveland, they will become the first team to win their division after losing 100 games the year prior. The issue for the Royals is that with a very tough rest of the schedule, it is unlikely that the Royals will win the division, but likely will receive a Wild Card bid.

Danny Jansen plays for both teams in a single game

Catcher Danny Jansen set history last weekend when he became the first player to play for both teams in one game. After a game between the Toronto Blue Jays and the Boston Red Sox was postponed this past June, Jansen was traded from Toronto to Boston. When that game finally resumed this week, Jansen flipped teams and was catching for the Red Sox in an at-bat that he was pinch-hit for. The oddity was a first in baseball history, as Jansen showed up on the scorecard for both teams.

The double play going into the weekend

Ohtani and the Dodgers are barely holding on to their three-game lead in the NL West. What quickly became the top division in baseball is now a fight for first place between LA, the San Diego Padres and the Arizona Diamondbacks. The Dodgers will travel to Phoenix to battle in a four-game series, which could decide who gets a first-round bye. Prediction: The Diamondbacks take three of four games.

The Royals still have work to do to overtake the Guardians for first place in the AL Central. For now, the team’s main goal should be securing a second-place position in the Wild Card race. The Houston Astros should provide the Royals with a solid first challenge as they tackle the backend of their schedule. Prediction: The Royals and Astros each take two games.

Last weekend the Yankees and Mariners both won their series, moving my prediction total to 7-11-2.

USC women’s volleyball opens inaugural Big Ten campaign at Pepperdine

The Trojans head up to Malibu to start the 2024 season.

Mia Tuaniga prepares for her fourth year with the Trojans, but her first in the Big Ten. (Photo by Elijah Patterson / Annenberg Media File Photo)

By Crash "CrashLit" Collier August 28, 2024 at 6:57 pm PDT

USC women’s volleyball will take the court on Friday and Saturday for back-to-back matches against the Pepperdine Waves in Malibu for their first matches as Big Ten Conference members. Last season, the Trojans went 19-13 and made it to the second round of the NCAA tournament.

Since the Trojans are in a new conference, head coach Brad Keller has adapted certain aspects of how the Trojans practice and play. Keller, though, was lucky to have more players around this offseason compared to last year, making the transition easier.

“We kinda just reconstructed our entire system, we play a very different style of volleyball then we did last year,” Keller said. “It took a lot of time to do that, but right now I like that product of what you see out there at this moment in time.”

USC’s reconstructed system will go up against a Pepperdine squad that went 19-9 with a 15-1 mark in WCC play last season. The Waves clinched their conference’s automatic berth in the NCAA tournament, but fell in the first round to Dayton in Pullman, Washington.

Because Pepperdine has appeared in four of the last five NCAAs under head coach Scott Wong, Keller knows that the Trojans will have their hands full this weekend against the Waves.

“Scott Wong and [his] staff at Pepperdine, they do an amazing job every single year,” Keller said. “There’s a reason why they’re making the tournament, there’s a reason why they keep winning their conference, there’s a reason that this is happening, so that team is going to be an NCAA tournament team, and maybe a deep run team, so we’re aware of that and excited for the opportunity.”

Despite the challenge that Pepperdine poses to USC, senior setter Mia Tuaniga is confident in her teammates’ abilities to step up and contribute to the team’s success this year.

“I think the team is different in the way that we have more people stepping into different roles and more people coming into leadership spaces, which I think is great,” Tuaniga said. “We’re starting to grow as a program, we’re starting to grow as individuals, which is really nice.”

Graduate outside hitter Ally Batenhorst, who transferred from Nebraska after three seasons with the Cornhuskers, understands the Big Ten and hopes to help her teammates adjust to playing the conference opponents she’s already familiar with.

“It’s a whole different conference and it’s the best volleyball conference in the nation,” Batenhorst said of the Big Ten’s volleyball reputation. “And it’s gonna be a lot of different teams and I think just being able to experience those games and experience that type of pressure is gonna really help me lead the team.”

As USC is preparing for its first matches as a Big Ten member, Keller praised the experience his staff has working for Big Ten programs. This has helped make the transition smoother, as technical coordinator Virgina Pham and associate head coaches Tyler Hildebrand and Spencer McLachlin know the midwest-based conference and its footprint quite well with regards to travel and hotels.

Pham spent two years as the director of operations at Penn State, while Hildebrand was at Nebraska prior to joining the Trojans and McLachlin brought his talents over from Indiana. Hildebrand and McLachlin have already been true to their roots in recruiting; Batenhorst is a prime example, coming over from Nebraska, along with graduate outside hitter Grae Gosnell, making the move to USC after four years at Indiana.

Regardless of how this opening weekend goes for USC, Keller knows that playing Pepperdine will help the coaches gauge the Trojans’ progress as they prepare to compete in their new conference.

“At the end of the day, whether you win or lose the first match, it’s a long season,” Keller said. “So being able to figure out where we actually are and where we need to get to and how to get there, kind of a roadmap, a first test is going to be really valuable for us.”

The Trojans kick off their season on Friday with a 6 p.m. start time at Pepperdine, following that up with a rematch against the Waves the following night at the same time.

The Talk of Troy Country Club Current: Sinner splits ways with coaches: “I just need some clean air.” The world No. 1 makes a big personnel change right before the final major of the year and is in hot water with the tennis community.

Jannik Sinner has had a breakout 2024 season, the validity of which is now in doubt amid an alleged doping scandal. (AP/Aurelien Morissard) 

By Robert Westermann August 28, 2024 at  6:33 pm PDT

Not more than five days after taking the crown at the Cincinnati Open, Jannik Sinner found himself embroiled in a doping scandal and subsequently parted ways with his trainer and physiotherapist. The timing couldn’t have been worse for the 2024 Australian Open champion, as the U.S. Open began Monday with Sinner among the favorites. Given his dominant performance at Cincinnati earlier this month, he likely would’ve been the favorite. Now, instead of riding the momentum into the final major of the year, he’ll have to play with a scandal in the back of his mind and new coaches by his side.

But Sinner, now 23, should be old enough to deal with being the center of attention on his own. Throughout his six years on the ATP tour, he’s never been a player known to rely heavily on his coach’s box for encouragement or tactical advice. He plays with a certain stoicism. Sinner’s only moment of celebration in the Cincinnati semifinal against Alexander Zverev was right after match point, when he let out all the emotions pent up from the three-hour, eight-minute battle. The match proved that even with a hip injury—seemingly more serious than initially evaluated—Sinner can and will fight to the very end.

The similarities between the two are there; hitting winners out of nowhere, having the stamina to play for hours upon hours and surviving rallies that seem to go on forever. Sinner’s energy and playstyle aren’t vastly different from that of fellow youngster Carlos Alcaraz, but unlike his Spanish competitor, Sinner doesn’t show much emotion. Sinner, though, appears to borrow one characteristic in particular from 24-time Grand Slam winner Novak Djokovic: nobody knows what’s going on inside his head. Djokovic is the type of player that seems invincible on an emotional level. There may be the occasional argument against the umpire or dispute with a line judge, but whether he’s winning or losing, Djokovic almost never gives his opponent the mental edge. Sinner is developing into a player with the same sort of positive arrogance, which he’ll need more than ever in Flushing Meadow.

The doping scandal itself, however, shows how important it is for athletes to be able to handle themselves while in the public eye. The media surrounds much of their coverage on the most famous athletes because they’re who fans want to see the most. It makes sense from a viewership perspective, but for athletes who haven’t handled that type of attention before, it can be overwhelming and devastating for their careers if they don’t learn how to manage it. Sinner’s fellow Italian and track superstar Marcell Jacobs is a prominent example of this from the last four years. At the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, Jacobs shocked the field when he took gold in the men’s 100-meter final. As a result, he became a sensation, gaining access to red carpets and featuring in sports documentaries. There’s nothing inherently wrong with that type of fame and luxury, and Jacobs earned it the hard way. Since then, however, he hasn’t been the same. The more he has opened up his life to the world, the less success he’s had, and the reigning gold medalist failed to reach the podium this summer in Paris. The 29-year-old has perhaps aged out of peak performance, but there’s no arguing that the media attention had something to do with the decline in performance.

In America, numerous athletes have gone down a similar path. Johnny “Football” Manziel was going to become the face of the NFL, but external influences and his inability to focus on developing his game got the better of him. Though the reasons behind these athletes’ declines differ, the pressure of being a big name in sports can weigh heavily on an athlete. For Sinner, the popularity won’t be too much for him to handle anytime soon, but instances like the one last week can’t happen too often if he wants to keep a level head. Any unnecessary attention from the media is the last thing he needs when he’s still at a developing point in his career. If Sinner wants to be amongst the greats, his focus needs to rest solely on his game. 2024 is just the beginning for him, and with the way he’s matured over the last few years, fans shouldn’t have to worry about Sinner disappearing anytime soon.

Kings prospect spotlight: Erik Portillo

The Kings extended the 23-year-old netminder following an impressive AHL stint. Expand Prospect goaltender Erik Portillo earned 24 victories during the 2023-24 AHL season—capturing the eyes of the Kings’ front office—which hopes for a long-term answer in net. (Photo via X/@NHLRussell)  By   Kasey Kazliner August 25, 2024 at  7:36 pm PDT

LOS ANGELES — Goaltending was never a question mark during the Los Angeles Kings’ Jonathan Quick era, but nearly a year and a half since his departure, the position has been far from a source of certainty. The Kings received All-Star level play from veteran Cam Talbot during the first half of the 2023-24 campaign, but after backup Pheonix Copley suffered a season-ending ACL injury, Talbot was forced to carry the bulk of weight in the crease and encountered an inconsistent spell. Newly acquired backstop Darcy Kuemper and journeyman David Rittich are set to split time in 2024-25, but general manager Rob Blake knew that he would need to look beyond the upcoming season and find a sustainable, long-term option. Thus, he drafted OHL standout  Carter George  in the second round of the 2024 draft and previously built up Los Angeles’ netminder pool through other means. But another young goaltender—Erik Portillo—has risen through the organization’s goaltender ranks, earning him a three-year contract extension to further prove his worth.

Portillo thrived with the AHL affiliate Ontario Reign last season, boasting a 24-11-3 record with a 2.5 goals-against average, a .918 save percentage and two shutouts. Portillo also led the Reign to five playoff victories in which he recorded an outstanding 2.16 goals-against average. The Swedish native first arrived in North America after he was selected by the Buffalo Sabres in the third round of the 2019 draft. He then went on to play for the University of Michigan in 2020-21 and later indicated that he wouldn’t sign with the Sabres, forcing Buffalo to trade him. On the same day that Los Angeles dealt Quick away, the team acquired Portillo in exchange for a 2023 third-round pick.

Portillo’s towering 6-foot-6, 225-pound frame allows him to operate differently than smaller goaltenders. He often keeps a lowered posture to make saves, and in conjunction with his size, he can shed angles without any issue. Erik Portillo ( #GoKingsGo ) makes another big save on the breakaway to keep  @umichhockey  within one of Quinnipiac. #MFrozenFour   pic.twitter.com/70KZ9KZu3d — EP Rinkside (@EPRinkside)  April 7, 2023

Portillo has a confident demeanor in the crease, almost daring opposing skaters to take shots as he generally stays within the painted area. Because of this trait, he rarely finds himself out of position and can swiftly navigate to the puck by moving easily between the posts. He hardly shows fatigue—even in vulnerable moments—when he gives up a goal or makes a mistake. His wide frame can sometimes hurt his game, as he sometimes misses saves on his pads or through the five-hole. He will also want to improve his awareness following initial shots, which will allow him to prevent rebound chances from finding their way in.

Set to turn 24 in September, Portillo brings experience to the Kings’ prospect pool after spending three seasons at Michigan and adding an AHL campaign to his resume. His biggest tests will be remaining consistent and handling the hefty workload that comes with being a professional. The first year of Portillo’s new deal will carry two-way stipulations. The prospect will likely be the Reign’s starting option in 2024-25, but if he can keep up his stellar figures, he might receive full-time NHL status sooner than expected.

Amid a new era of Kings goaltending, the team is searching for a consistent option to anchor the net. Whether it be Portillo or another up-and-comer that takes the reins, Blake and company will have their eyes on Los Angeles’ prospect pool this season, which consists of multiple promising netminders auditioning to take the role. Portillo’s professional career is just beginning, and if he can continue his upward trajectory, the Kings will greatly benefit from the tall, composed backstop’s progress.

Welcome back, Trojans! It’s been a busy three months at USC, even in the absence of most undergraduate students. Annenberg Media kept up to date on happenings around the university and beyond while you were gone — here are the six stories that captured our attention the most.

Carol Folt remains president of USC for an unspecified length of time
President Folt delivers state of the university address in Bovard Auditorium. Annenberg Media started asking questions in early July about Folt’s five-year contract with the university, which was set to expire on the first day of the month. Folt’s handling of commencement and protests during the spring semester called her leadership into question among students and faculty, and resulted in the Academic Senate censuring her and Provost Andrew Guzman. For more than a week, the status of Folt’s presidency — and what her capacity was in helming the university — seemed to be in limbo. On July 9, a university spokesperson told Annenberg Media that President Folt’s contract had been “amended and extended.” The university would not provide further details about why Folt’s contract had been amended, what the amendment included or for how long her tenure had been extended. The spokesperson did say, though, that the decision had been made before her contract’s July 1 expiration date. Moving into the fall, the terms of Folt’s contract with the university are still unclear.

Fatal stabbing on Greek Row
Police found the deceased victim in the alleyway behind fraternity houses Delta Tau Delta and Lambda Chi Alpha at 8:15 p.m. on Monday, June 18. In June, a USC student was arrested for fatally stabbing a man who was breaking into a car on Greek Row. Ivan Gallegos, the student, returned home following the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s decision not to charge him in connection with Xavier Cerf’s death. On June 17, Gallegos and two of his friends confronted Cerf, who was inside Gallegos’ roommate’s car. According to the DA, Cerf told Gallegos that he was armed with a gun and reached for his hip. Gallegos stabbed Cerf four times, and Cerf later died from his injuries in an alley off Greek Row. Gallegos was arrested on the night of June 17 and booked on murder charges. DA George Gascón said on June 24 that he believed Gallegos’s actions “were driven by a genuine fear for his life and for the lives of others” and announced that he would not press charges against Gallegos. Following Gallegos’s arrest, his family started several GoFundMe fundraisers to pay for his $2 million bail. The fundraisers accumulated a combined $10,000 but were removed each time by the platform. Yema Jones, Xavier Cerf’s mother, started a separate GoFundMe to return his remains to his home in Texas and raised $5,600 before the fundraiser ended.

Administration rolls out discipline against students involved in spring protests
DPS officers walk past the USC Divest From Death encampment as protesters chant, May 1, 2024. USC’s Office of Community Expectations (OCE) disciplined students this summer who were arrested on April 24 in connection with the occupation of Alumni Park. In interviews with Annenberg Media, students involved in the disciplinary process and the faculty advising them described their interactions with administrators. The occupation was organized by the USC Divest from Death Coalition and included a list demands like a “complete academic boycott of Israel,” “full amnesty” for students involved in pro-Palestinian activism and the “protect[ion] of free speech on campus.” LAPD arrested 48 students at the occupation, and USC placed at least 29 on interim suspension. According to the Coalition, more than 75 students now face discipline. The students who were suspended in May still remain on suspension and are not allowed on campus, a spokesperson for the Coalition said. Most of the students who were suspended chose a full administrative review process over a “proposed resolution” from OCE. Those processes are “at or near completion,” according to a USC spokesperson. Some disciplined students have been required to write “remorseful” essays, and others who worked as residential assistants who received free housing are unclear about the status of their jobs. Several students are worried because they have been advised by their legal counsel that the essays could be used as evidence in a criminal case brought by the LAPD. One student was told that the LAPD had up to a year to bring charges for criminal trespassing.

Popular stores and restaurants close, others open
The entrance of Yoboseyo Superette, a new boba shop and Asian market in the USC Village owned by the same couple as Cafe Dulce. The storefronts of the USC Village continued to shuffle during the summer months. Stout, a burger pub, and Pizza Please, the Village’s only pizza joint, closed after short tenures — less than two years of serving customers. Also gone is Workshop Salon + Boutique, a spot for haircuts and blowouts; the space was converted into storage for the neighboring Target. Meanwhile, the units previously occupied by Honeybird, a Southern-style breakfast and lunch eatery, and the Sammiche Shoppe remain vacant. Some empty spaces have been filled, though. The international beauty giant Sephora opened a Village location on July 26, moving into a unit that had been uninhabited since 2019 (its previous tenants had sued USC after moving out). Yoboseyo Superette, an Asian market with an original location in Little Tokyo, moved into the village as a “sister concept” to Cafe Dulce on July 20. The store serves specialty boba drinks and snacks and is located next to the USC Roski Eye Institute. Students may also mourn the loss of Study Hall, a sports bar and restaurant that permanently closed just before its tenth anniversary. Its space on the corner of Hoover Street and West 29th Street has already been filled by Roadside Taco, a Mexican restaurant.

Trojan Olympic performance
Junior midfielder Croix Bethune (7) goes for the ball during USC's Nov. 5 match against UCLA. Trojan athletes won a combined total of 15 medals at the 2024 Summer Olympics. USC saw 65 athletes compete in Paris, which was more than any other U.S. university, but the Trojans came in fourth place for medals among American universities — it was beaten by Texas, California and Stanford. USC athletes earned seven gold medals and took silver in two events. Still, the 15-medal total is the lowest Summer Games showing from the Trojans this century. Standout athletes included Rai Benjamin, a USC track and field star who won two gold medals for Team USA, along with TeeTee Terry, Aaron Brown and Andre de Grasse, who are also track and field athletes who carried their teams to gold victories. Anni Espar, who played women’s water polo for Spain, and Croix Bethune, an American women’s soccer player, also won gold for their countries. If USC were its own country, it would have placed sixteenth at the Olympics. You can also read Annenberg Media’s profiles of the Trojans who competed in water polo, track and field, swim and dive, and other teams including volleyball and rowing.

Shake-ups in the university’s top administration
Stacy Giwa, USC's new interim senior vice president of human relations. Although President Folt’s time at USC will continue, other senior administrators have left the university. Folt announced on June 14 that Felicia Washington, the university’s first senior vice president of human resources, would leave at the end of August. Washington’s appointment in 2019 was significant. Under her tenure, she united several offices — the Office for Equity, Equal Opportunity, and Title IX, the Office of Professionalism and Ethics and the Office of Culture, Ethics and Compliance — into a larger human resources department. She also was responsible for implementing “Tyndall-related requirements,” according to Folt’s announcement. Washington will lead human relations at the University of Pennsylvania. Stacy Giwa, the vice president of culture, ethics and compliance will start the role of interim vice president on October 1. Washington’s departure follows Provost Guzman’s May 29 announcement that Amber Miller would step down as dean of Dornsife College to lead the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation. Miller, an experimental astrophysicist, was the longest-serving dean of Dornsife since the 1950s and led the college through “some of the most challenging times in the university’s history,” according to USC Dornsife. Moh El-Naggar, a physicist and Dornsife professor, filled Miller’s spot as interim dean on June 15. Kedra Ishop, the vice president for enrollment management, left her position on August 15 to join the College Board in a higher education role. In her previous role, Ishop managed university admissions, registrar’s offices and financial aid. She was also an adjunct associate professor in the Rossier School of Education. Ishop’s tenure was notable for offering USC’s Affordability Initiative, which awards free tuition to first-year undergraduate students whose families make $80,000 or less each year. Timothy Brunold, USC’s former dean of admission, now serves as interim vice president for enrollment management.

Giesler’s Grand Slam: Seattle Mariners part ways with Scott Servais

Talks of a rule change, Aaron Judge chases 60 home runs for the second time and the double play going into the weekend.

Aaron Judge continues to edge his way closer to 60 home runs. (Photo courtesy of the New York Yankees)

By Andrew Giesler
August 23, 2024 at 9:50 am PDT

Mariners fire manager Servais

The Seattle Mariners have been tumbling down the AL West leaderboard since June. Despite a 10-game advantage, they’ve gone 12-18 since the All-Star break and are now five games behind a hot Houston Astros team. They are a top pitching squad in the league, but the team can’t find ways to keep up offensively. They have the worst batting average and the fewest hits in the league, in addition to striking out more often than the rest of the league. Their struggles in the batter’s box level out any defensive advantage the team has.

In an attempt to change things up, the front office fired manager Scott Servais during his ninth season with the program. His temporary replacement is Dan Wilson, who has been in the organization’s minor league system for 13 years. Although it is more likely an issue with the team itself instead of the manager, fans hope that Wilson can light a spark in the team and push them toward an unlikely playoff appearance.

Starting pitchers may see longer on-field stints

The MLB recently discussed a new rule that would require starters to stay in the game longer which has caused mixed reviews. Some think it’s important to keep the role of starting pitcher alive, but the six-inning rule is not the way to do it. Starting pitchers’ roles have started to diminish in recent years, with relievers taking over earlier and teams going to the bullpen more often. Kansas City Royals starter Seth Lugo said that most starters want to be relieved early on in games, but it just doesn’t work out like that most times.

To combat this, the rule that the league proposed would require starting pitches to throw a mandatory six innings. The only exceptions to the rule are if a pitcher throws more than 100 pitches, lets up four runs in an inning or gets injured. This proposal is yet another attempt by the league to make the game of baseball more appealing to viewers. Higher pitch counts result in more fatigue, allowing batters to hit the ball more often. For players, though, the potential new rule may put too much strain on starters’ arms.

The new pitch clock is one rule that affects a pitcher’s arm, decreasing the time of rest and increasing the activation time of the muscles. The reduced pitch clock has resulted in more Tommy John injuries. Another rule is the sticky-stuff rule. The MLB cracked down on pitchers using illegal substances, which forced most pitchers to change their style in the middle of the season, putting even more strain on the arm.

Judge continues to chase 60 home runs

AL MVP frontrunner Aaron Judge is chasing history yet again. Earlier this month, Judge became the quickest player to hit 300 home runs, and looks to become the third player to hit more than 60 home runs in consecutive years. If Judge were to achieve these feats, the Yankee would cement himself as one of the greatest hitters of all time beside fellow 60 home-run hitters Sammy Sosa and Mark McGwire. Judge separates himself from Sosa and McGwire in the fact that the latter two had steroid allegations throughout their entire career, especially during their peak seasons. Sosa was not officially caught doing illegal substances, but his build and power raised many eyebrows. McGwire eventually came clean about his steroid usage.

There is a lot of ball left to play, but given how Judge is already at 48 home runs with 24 games left to play, he’s well on his way. The double play going into the weekend

Judge and the New York Yankees have a home series scheduled against the Colorado Rockies. The key for Judge throughout these games will be to pass the 50-home run marker and move closer to history. With a tough finish to the season, it is imperative that Judge can move forward now.

Prediction: The Yankees will sweep the Rockies.

With Wilson now at the helm, the Mariners need to start winning if they want any hope of a playoff bid. As a team that historically chokes toward the ends of the season, it is a very big stretch for the Mariners to play in October. A home series win against the San Francisco Giants, however, would do wonders and give the team momentum heading into an easy stretch of their schedule.

Prediction: The Mariners win two of three.

Last weekend the Reds and Guardians both lost their series, moving my prediction total to 5-11-2.

USC football’s comradery strengthens as the 2024 season approaches

A new coaching staff and simpler schemes have USC’s defenders feeling more confident going into the season.

The USC defense is rearing up for its first game of the season. (Photo by Wesley Chen)

By Daniel Palmore August 22, 2024 at 4:03 pm PDT

Throughout USC’s disappointing outing in the 2023 season, miscues defined a majority of the Trojans’ struggles, especially on the defensive side of the ball. The defense allowing big plays because of blown coverages was the main reason why the unit surrendered a staggering 35 points per game, second to last in the Pac-12 a season ago. To fix this glaring issue, USC fired defensive coordinator Alex Grinch during the season and hired the former defensive coordinator for the UCLA Bruins, D’Anton Lynn. In his one and only season as UCLA’s defensive coordinator, the Bruins allowed the fewest yards per game in the Pac-12 with 299 and the fewest points, allowing just 18 per game.

So far in practice, USC’s defenders have noticed the differences in playing defense under Lynn and the former defensive coaching staff. “Not having to overthink or worry about doing your assignment is the biggest thing,” senior linebacker Eric Gentry said. “I feel like it’s way more straightforward this year, more NFL style.”

If USC’s defense is going to improve in the Trojans’ inaugural season in the Big Ten, Gentry is a player that will be relied upon heavily. Gentry’s durability will be critical for the Trojans as his numbers from last season were down across the board compared to his 2022 season after appearing in only eight games in the regular season. Gentry’s unique physical traits make him one of the most versatile players on the Trojans’ defense. Standing at 6-foot-6, Gentry has a 7-foot-1 wingspan which makes it difficult for opposing quarterbacks to fit passes into areas he is covering.

Gentry believes the new player-coach dynamic for USC will be able to help him maximize his potential this season. “It’s an open book for both of us,” Gentry said. “Coaches listen to what the players have to say and players completely understand what the coaches have to say.”

Heading into this season, the Trojans have also been building up their on-field chemistry by spending more time with each other away from practice. Redshirt sophomore safety Kamari Ramsey makes it a priority to build a strong rapport with his teammates outside of the game of football. “Not everything’s about football, it’s just a game,” Ramsey said. “We’ve just been spending time with each other, going to each other’s houses and just doing things outside of football that don’t relate to football.”

Ramsey, who played his first two seasons of college football at UCLA, followed Lynn to USC to help bolster the Trojans’ secondary. Last season for the Bruins, Ramsey recorded 40 total tackles, four pass breakups and one interception in 11 games. The former Bruin believes a critical piece to his improvement this upcoming season will be more trust in himself and his abilities to master Lynn’s defensive scheme. “Last year, I caught myself hesitating sometimes,” Ramsey said. “Plays I knew I could make I didn’t make so I kind of left a few of plays on the table, but this year I’m trusting myself.”

Along with Ramsey, other players followed Lynn to USC, including redshirt senior cornerback John Humphrey. Last season, Humphrey was tied for second on the Bruins’ defense in interceptions and notched two forced fumbles. Humphrey also had three pass breakups and 22 solo tackles. It was a big offseason for Humphrey, who had a “little procedure” that caused him to miss the majority of spring camp, according to head coach Lincoln Riley. Humphrey has recovered, slotting in as a consistent participant in fall camp and is ready for the beginning of the season. “I’m feeling pretty good and I’m just trusting the process,” Humphrey said. “My mind was always still in the game. It was about knocking off the rust for me, and I still am until game one.”

With kickoff less than two weeks away, the Trojans’ confidence in their new scheme and coaching staff should give USC fans reason to be optimistic about the season. No. 13 LSU will be a big test for the Trojans on September 1 and a great opportunity for USC to showcase its new scheme and stronger chemistry.

The legacy of USC football and how it fits in 2024

From McKay to Riley: How USC Created an Everlasting Dynasty in the College Football Landscape.

With Caleb Williams now in the NFL, a new squad will have to carry on the legacy of USC football. (Photo by Wesley Chen)

By Harrison Fuller August 22, 2024 at 3:57 pm PDT

Caleb Williams is gone to the NFL. Is this the end of an era? Many posed the same question when Keyshawn Johnson left. They did the same when Reggie Bush and Matt Leinart departed. From the John McKay-led Trojans in the 1960s, to the current team led by Lincoln Riley, USC has always been a team that is likely to be at the top of the college football rankings. The storied program has had 16 undefeated seasons and nine perfect seasons in its history while its 70% winning percentage is seventh all-time in the FBS. USC has ruled the west.

Historically, fans believed that nothing could get in the way of the Trojan legacy in college football. But new concerns have risen as the Trojans enter the Big Ten conference in 2024. Analysts have speculated that USC’s play in the trenches and their linebacking corp will hold them back in the Big Ten.

Despite the criticism, Trojan head coach Lincoln Riley still has his eyes on the prize. “Our goal has been to come here and win national championships. That’s been the goal,” Riley said in an interview with CBS Sports analyst Adam Breneman. “To do that you have to be good enough to beat everybody, including Big Ten teams and anybody else.”

The earliest, and possibly biggest test for the Trojans this season, is when they head to Ann Arbor in Week 3 to face the reigning national champion, Michigan. Both teams have come up in conversations about who has lost the most assets heading into next season. USC lost its Heisman trophy-winning quarterback, along with two solid pass catchers from last year in Tahj Washington and Brenden Rice. Michigan, compared to USC, lost much more since last year. The Wolverines lost the most valuable asset a team can lose — their head coach Jim Harbaugh, who left for the Los Angeles Chargers’ job. Not only is Harbaugh gone, but so is Michigan’s quarterback JJ McCarthy, their leading rusher Blake Corum and five key players from their defense.

This matchup will be a true evaluation of whether the Trojans can bounce back from losing a star player. It’s a good thing USC has already proven to be very good at that. When Reggie Bush left for the NFL after his illustrious career at USC, the feeling with Trojan fans was that USC was done for. Not only were they losing their Heisman-winning running back, but they were also losing their Heisman-winning quarterback, Matt Leinart.

After going 12-1 in 2005 with their only loss coming to Texas in the Rose Bowl, the Trojans rebounded to heights no one could have predicted. Led by quarterback John David Booty, they went 11-2 and bested Michigan in the Rose Bowl. But they didn’t just win one Rose Bowl after Bush and Leinart left — they won the next three between 2007 and 2009.

Although they might seem similar at first sight, the 2006 USC team and this squad going into next year do have one stark difference; defense. The teams of the early 2000s were known not only for their explosive offenses but also their tough, reliable defenses. Players like Troy Polamalu, Brian Cushing, and Rey Maualuga anchored those defenses and helped keep the Trojans atop the defensive rankings in college football.

The 2023 Trojans, on the other hand, finished near the bottom of the FBS in yards allowed and total defense. Even with their electric offense led by Caleb Williams, the defense hindered the team as a whole’s success and the Trojans finished the season with an 8-5 record, and being left out of the final AP Top-25 poll.

So even though both the 2006 team and the 2024 team suffered major losses from the year prior and were looking to rebound, defensive play will be a major factor in if the Trojans want to improve as a whole in 2024.

But even though the times look rough right now, I think USC will still be USC, finding ways to beat the odds and win.

The Birth of a Dynasty

In the 1950s, USC couldn’t find any stability in the coaching realm, having three different coaches throughout the decade. They wanted to get back to the dynasty they had in the 1930s, where they won two national championships. To do this, they looked to an unknown assistant coach by the name of John McKay.

McKay came into the 1960 season with fairly high expectations, as the Trojans accumulated an 8-2 record the year before under head coach Don Clark. But McKay’s first season couldn’t have gone much worse than it did. The first-year head coach’s team lost embarrassingly to conference rivals like Washington and Oregon State, suffering shutout losses to both.

Year two wasn’t much better. The Trojans eked out a 4-5-1 record that included a 0-0 tie against Washington. But year three is when the McKay-led Trojans turned the corner and never looked back. They went an astounding 11-0 and won their first national championship since 1932.

McKay went on to coach at USC for 16 seasons, producing three more national championships and USC’s first two Heisman winners, Mike Garrett and O.J. Simpson. Then, finally, in 1976, McKay handed the reins to John Robinson as McKay left to become the first head coach of the NFL’s newest expansion team, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

Robinson continued the dynasty, adding another national championship to USC’s trophy case, along with two more Heisman winners, Charles White and Marcus Allen. But those two would be USC’s last Heisman winners for a very long time. The Trojans would have to wait until 2002 to see another one of their own hoist up the prestigious award.

The Pete Carroll Era

In 2000, USC hired Pete Carroll to be its head coach after the three-year disaster that was the Paul Hackett regime. Carroll had been a coach in the NFL for some time, but had never found lasting success at the professional level.

“My style of football ... I have always taught an aggressive, attacking style,” Carroll said in his opening press conference after being hired in December 2000.

And attack Carroll did. In his second season coaching the Trojans, Carroll led them to an 11-1 season and an Orange Bowl victory. Not only that, but his quarterback, Carson Palmer, won the Heisman.

Even though a season with a single loss doesn’t seem like there is much room for improvement, Carroll and USC did one better in 2003. The Trojans bested Michigan in the Rose Bowl and took home the national championship for the first time since the John Robinson era.

Carroll continued this dominant era, accumulating another national championship the very next year in 2004. Even with all of his success as a coach, Carroll did have some heartbreak. In the 2005 Rose Bowl, the No. 1-ranked Trojans faced No. 2-ranked Texas. It was Leinart and Bush versus Vince Young, the three Heisman finalists that season.

Even before the game started, the crowd knew it would be one for the ages. Although USC fans were excited to see if Bush and Leinart could lead the Trojans to the promised land as one last ride before they were off to the NFL, there was a looming sense of sadness knowing that dynamic duo put on cardinal and gold ever again.

Leinart and Bush were some of the most exciting players college football had ever seen up to that point. “You didn’t know what kind of play was going to come next ... Anything is possible with [Leinart and Bush],” said JaBari Brown, a director of undergraduate advisement at USC Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism.

But that night in Pasadena, not everything was possible for the Trojans. Texas’ Young dashed to the corner of the endzone for a touchdown with 20 seconds left to win the natty for the Longhorns.

Trojan fans couldn’t even imagine what 2006 was going to be like without a national championship, without Leinart and without Bush. But even after all those losses, Carroll kept the Trojans on top. The Trojans did not have a season with under nine wins for the rest of the Carroll regime.

Carroll had such an extraordinary resumé while at USC, that he caught the attention of the NFL. He went on to leave USC for the Seattle Seahawks in 2010 just as the NCAA laid down sanctions on the Trojans that left the program crippled for the start of the 2010s.

Since then, the Trojans have had five different head coaches and haven’t had a star to the same caliber of Bush. Until a transfer by the name of Caleb Williams came into town in 2022.

The Current Era: Questions About the Big Ten

Typically, USC’s dynasties have had both a Heisman winner and a team that performed well. Unlike almost any other time in history, the 2022 USC team had a Heisman winner in Williams, but failed to finish in the top-5 teams in the Associated Press Top 25 Poll. The only other time this has happened for the Trojans was when Marcus Allen won the Heisman trophy in 1981, but the Trojans finished the season ranked No. 14 in the poll.

Now, USC’s Heisman winner is gone and they’re coming off an 8-5 season in 2023. Not only that, they will move out of the Pac-12 into the Big Ten, known for its tough teams like Michigan and Ohio State.

Analysts have questioned whether the Trojans can keep up with the Big Ten’s “corn-fed boys,” as former NFL wide receiver, USC alum and now Fox Sports personality Keyshawn Johnson puts it.

In the 2024 NFL Draft, the Big Ten produced a far majority of offensive lineman compared to the Pac-12. But historically, USC has been a school that has produced high quality NFL lineman, including Bruce Matthews, Anthony Muñoz and Tyron Smith.

If the Trojans can summon the legacies of these past greats, they should be able to keep up with the Michigans and the Iowas when it comes to the trenches next season.

USC will definitely have an adjustment period with its move to a new conference, but Big Ten play won’t be all that different from what they already experienced in the Pac-12. In the final AP Top 25 rankings of the 2023 season, the Pac-12 and the Big Ten were represented equally, both putting three rankings into the rankings.

But USC will be joined by some of its former Pac-12 opponents in the Big Ten this year. Oregon, Washington and UCLA are coming along with them, as the Huskies and the Bruins are on the schedule this year.

So, really, USC has already gotten a taste of what some of its Big Ten competition will look like. With that being said, Big Ten powerhouses like Michigan and Penn State are on USC’s schedule this year.

But, at the end of the day, the Trojans have all they need to put up a fight against their new conference foes for years to come.

USC defense ready for a reset in 2024

After a historically dismal season, USC’s new defensive staff looks to improve in the new season.

Jaylin Smith (No. 19) and Prophet Brown (No. 16) pursue Louisville back Isaac Guerendo in the Holiday Bowl. Both Smith and Brown are expected to be major pieces of USC's new defense. (Photo by Wesley Chen)

By Nick Charles Currie August 20, 2024 at 6:32 pm PDT

USC fans rejoiced when defensive coordinator Alex Grinch was fired midway through the 2023 season. His replacement, D’Anton Lynn — poached from crosstown rival UCLA — promised a new, more normal approach for the upcoming season. When asked of his top priorities defensively, Lynn simply said “stopping the run and affecting the quarterback.” That may seem like a boring answer, but it marks a shift from the Grinch era, who focused more on forcing turnovers than working on the fundamentals.

“We don’t look at takeaways defensively as being the extra,” Grinch told reporters ahead of the 2022 season, his first with USC. “We look at that as the sole purpose why we take the field.” That worked, to an extent, in his first year with the Trojans. Grinch’s group forced the ninth-most turnovers in the FBS. It only resulted in the No. 94 scoring defense, but it gave the Trojan offense good field position on route to an 11-3 record and NY6 Bowl berth. There was room to grow, but also a potential proof of concept.

In 2023, however, the wheels fell off. Turnover production regressed, with USC generating the 27th-fewest turnovers in college football. That drop in turnovers coincided with a jump in points allowed — to more than 34, the thirteenth most in the country. The Trojans dropped to an 8-5 record.

While his goals were not the most specific, Lynn did give some indications as to what his defense would look like. Lynn comes from the dual-Harbaugh tree of defensive coordinating. In 2021, Jim Harbaugh’s Michigan poached safeties coach Mike MacDonald from John Harbaugh’s Baltimore Ravens to run the Wolverines’ defense. The next year, MacDonald returned to the Ravens, but Michigan kept a similar system in place with new DC Jesse Minter who had also worked under John Harbaugh already. The system has been highly successful. Michigan made the playoffs in MacDonald’s one year with the team and won the national championship under Minter, who has since followed Jim Harbaugh to the Los Angeles Chargers. MacDonald’s system worked well enough in Baltimore that he became Pete Carroll’s successor as head coach of the Seattle Seahawks. Lynn has already shown that his version of the system is successful, elevating UCLA’s defense from 42nd worst to 14th best.

“The scheme has enough flexibility in it that, in my opinion, when I watch people who come from this scheme, it looks like we all run different schemes,” Lynn said. “When I watched Michigan last year, it doesn’t look like UCLA. When I watch some Baltimore stuff, that looks different than Michigan and I’m sure Seattle’s stuff is gonna look real different. So everyone kind of has their own twist on it.”

What does that scheme entail? Lynn discussed his desire to throw the kitchen sink at the quarterback. “We’d like to blitz. We play aggressive, we call the game aggressive,” Lynn said. “We’re just going to do it no matter what.” New defensive backs coach Doug Belk sounded excited at that prospect. “It all starts with the quarterback and as much as we can affect the quarterback on a down in and down [out] basis,” Belk said. “Whether it’s blitzes and disguises or playing coverage, that gives us in the secondary a greater chance to be successful.”

Although blitzing takes players out of coverage, Belk expressed that the trade-offs — that the ball has to come out sooner and the offense’s route tree is therefore less diverse — more than made up for that negative.

It’s not just the scheme that’s changing. Only defensive line coach Shaun Nua returned from last year’s staff, serving as co-interim defensive coordinator after Grinch’s firing. The new-look Trojan defensive staff has a wide range of experience. New linebackers coach Matt Entz went 60-11 as the head coach at North Dakota State in the FCS, winning two national championships in four years. Belk was the defensive coordinator at Houston for three years before coming to USC. Defensive line coach Eric Henderson held the same position with the Rams, also serving as the run game coordinator.

“I’m an information guy. I want information from as many places as I can get it. Whether that’s a former head coach like Entz or whether that’s a [graduate assistant],” Lynn said. “I think good ideas come from everywhere and if you want to grow as a coach, you can’t block yourself off the ideas from other people”

Belk echoed the value of the experience in the defensive coaching room. “Being able to learn from a bunch of veteran guys like coach Entz, who’s been a coordinator and a head coach, coach [Henderson] who’s been in the NFL for a long time, coach Nua, who’s been at a lot of different college stops and, ultimately, coach Lynn,” Belk said. “It’s helping me grow as it’s helping our players grow.”

There’s room for USC’s defense to improve on last year’s performance. It will face a tough first challenge, though, when the Trojans open the season against No. 13 LSU in Las Vegas on September 1.

USC Housing workers call off strike after reaching tentative agreement with USC

The deal marks the third agreement between employee unions and the university to avoid a strike in the last year.

USC housing workers prepare to strike outside of Century Apartments. (Photo courtesy of SEIU Local 721)

By Sophie Sullivan
August 20, 2024 at 5:29 pm PDT

USC housing workers called off a strike planned for Wednesday after reaching a tentative agreement with the university. The five-year contract, which workers ratified Tuesday, will raise wages, improve work schedules and introduce new job rights and protections for employees.

This is the third strike that the university has narrowly avoided in the last year, after USC shuttle drivers threatened to strike in May and graduate students picketed six months earlier.

“We are pleased that we were able to reach a contract agreement with our maintenance workers at USC Housing after a negotiation session on Monday,” USC Housing said in an email statement.

Last June, about 30 maintenance employees, painters, technicians and customer service representatives voted to join the Service Employees International Union under SEIU Local 721. On Thursday, they threatened to walk off the job over what they called unfair labor practices by USC.

Workers had also previously filed a charge with the National Labor Relations Board saying the university retaliated against their unionization by ending yearly merit-based raises. They also alleged “bad-faith bargaining tactics” by the university.

Dodgers take care of Cardinals

Despite injuries, the Los Angeles Dodgers still took the series over the St. Louis Cardinals. Expand Clayton Kershaw pitched six shutout innings in the Dodgers' 2-1 win over the St. Louis Cardinals. 
(Photo courtesy of the Los Angeles Dodgers @dodgers)  By   Andrew Giesler August 20, 2024 at  2:20 pm PDT 

The LA Dodgers took down the St. Louis Cardinals on Friday and Sunday, improving their division lead over the San Diego Padres to three games. With just two months left in the regular season, Los Angeles is still trying to figure out their ever-changing pitching rotation. River Ryan, who made his big league debut earlier this year, is out for the season and will undergo Tommy John surgery. The young star let up very few runs, primarily by forcing ground and fly outs with his dynamic arsenal. Tyler Glasnow joins Ryan on the injured list with elbow tendinitis and would like to avoid visiting Tommy John for the second time in his major league career. Yoshinobu Yamamoto has been out since June and is yet to play in a minor-league rehab game. His high speed fastballs and devastating breaking balls was a backbone for the Dodgers, and he quickly garnered six wins early in the season. The Padres and the Arizona Diamondbacks are two of the other teams that make up the dominant NL West, and they are clearly visible in the Dodgers’ mirror. The pressure is on LA to keep winning games, but by playing their stars night after night, the team has been riddled with injuries. Game 1 was a high-scoring affair, as Los Angeles came out on top 7-6. Kevin Kiermaier, who was traded to the Dodgers just before the deadline earlier this season, had a solid performance with four RBIs and his first home run in the blue and white. The Cardinals got the best of the Dodgers in Game 2, falling 5-2. Los Angeles was outhit 11-4, and managed just seven bases in the game. LA’s Shohei Ohtani hit a home run, which was one of the few bright spots for the Dodgers. LA first-baseman Freddie Freeman left the game early after bruising his finger on a ground ball, but luckily his X-rays showed no fracture and he won’t be out long. The Dodgers’ pitching held down a 2-1 win in Game 3. LA starting pitcher Clayton Kershaw had been disappointing up until Sunday, but he’s now headed in the right direction after two combined great starts.  His six-inning, 70-pitch display showed that he is both on a pitch cap and a strict-inning cap. Ohtani also added another homer on top of his Game 2 bomb, moving his season total to 39. Dodger fans still dream of a truly healthy squad. If all the stars align correctly, the team may be at full strength come October. As far as pitchers go, reliever Blake Treinen is working his way through a rehab stint in Double-A. He faced three batters this past Saturday, striking out all of them. Another reliever, Brusdar Graterol, is set to throw a bullpen session soon. After returning to the Major Leagues earlier this month, he quickly reinjured himself with a hamstring strain. Starting pitchers Glasnow and Yamamoto will return at an undisclosed time later this season, which will fill any gaps left in the starting rotation. There are numerous position players who are returning soon as well. Shortstop Tommy Edman will be activated from the IL within the next few days. The former Cardinal will provide great depth in the field and be another powerful hitter. Third-baseman Max Muncy will join the squad very soon as well. His oblique injury, which put him on the 60-day IL, has since been dealt with and he hopes to jump back into the lineup. Muncy has been a threat in the batters box every year for LA. The added support to Ohtani and Freeman will easily make LA’s lineup the best in the league. Known for his playoff performances as a Dodger, Chris Taylor is still going through his rehab assignment for a groin injury last month. Although he struggled early this season, he is still a great asset to the team when it comes to postseason time. The Dodgers now face a top-pitching squad in the  Seattle Mariners.

Dodgers split series with Brewers

Mookie Betts comes up big in his return for Los Angeles.

Will Smith smashed a home run in Game 2 against the Milwaukee Brewers. (Photo courtesy of the Los Angeles Dodgers @dodgers)

By Andrew Giesler
August 17, 2024 at 5:15 am PDT

LOS ANGELES – The LA Dodgers’ explosive offense got back on track against the Brewers with Mookie Betts back in the lineup. The versatile Betts has played all over the field for the Dodgers this season, which has come in handy with all the team’s injuries. Betts didn’t need much time to get used to the batter’s box, either, hitting a two-run homer in his second at-bat in the series.

The only difference between pre-and post-injury Betts is his position in the batting order. Normally the Dodgers’ lead-off hitter, Betts has taken a back seat to DH Shohei Ohtani. Also a speed demon, Ohtani has the third most steals in the league at 35 and has only been caught four times.

With third-baseman Max Muncy returning soon, the batting order will quickly become the deepest in the MLB. With their newly-added depth, the Dodgers showed off on both sides of the ball in a 5-2 Game 1 victory. Clayton Kershaw was the star in Game 1, reinstating confidence in Dodger fans after he was spotty in his first couple of starts back from injury. He finished with six strikeouts, one run and three hits, nearly making it six innings. The Dodgers did well clearing the bases, leaving only four players on.

Game 2 was a 7-2 no-doubter. Will Smith, Ohtani and Gavin Lux all hit home runs, while the team recorded 13 hits and 28 bases. Gavin Stone and Landon Knack held it down on the mound, and the two pitchers threw for a combined eight strikeouts on six hits.

The Dodgers struggled offensively in Game 3. The 5-4 loss was rare, with no Dodgers hitting any home runs. The bright spot in the loss was pitcher Walker Buehler, who returned from the injury list and threw three-and-a-third innings. He struggled during his first appearance in nearly two months, walking four and giving up four runs, though only one was earned.

Game 4 was a near-repeat of Game 3, where the Dodgers could not hit a home run despite ten hits. Starting pitcher Jack Flaherty continued to do well in a 6-4 loss, striking out seven batters in five innings. Second-baseman Lux is also showing promise, going two-for-three with a walk.

As the fourth quarter of the season begins, the NL West has defined itself as the best in the MLB. The 71-51 Dodgers are being hunted down by the Arizona Diamondbacks and San Diego Padres, who have both won nine of their last ten games. All three teams have been blistering hot since the All-Star break: LA going 15-10, Arizona 20-5 and San Diego 19-4. San Diego has the most manageable schedule going into October, with the Dodgers having a tough stretch before ending with six games against the Rockies. The Diamondbacks also have a very tough road ahead and finish the season against the Padres. Each team has its work cut out before the playoffs, but the Dodgers’ two-game cushion should be enough to keep the top spot.

USC housing workers threaten strike over “bad-faith” negotiations

Maintenance staff, technicians, painters and customer service representatives say they plan to walk off the job over unfair labor practices on the last day of fall move-in.

USC housing workers prepare to strike outside of Century Apartments. (Photo courtesy of SEIU Local 721)

By Tomoki Chien and Sophie Sullivan
August 16, 2024 at 10:41 am PDT

USC housing workers are threatening to strike next week in response to what they called illegal bargaining practices on the part of the university. Roughly 30 workers — including maintenance staff, technicians, painters and customer service representatives — say they plan to walk off the job.

“Our negotiations have been severely hurt by USC managers’ disrespect, retaliation, and bad-faith bargaining,” said Angel Moreno, a maintenance worker, in a press release. “We deserve much better.”

The housing workers accused the university of illegally ending its typical practice of awarding annual, merit-based raises as a retaliation tactic during negotiations.

“We are still actively engaged in negotiations over wages,” USC Housing wrote in a statement. “We have been and will continue to bargain in good faith.”

USC Housing added that it has a “contingency plan in place for Aug. 21′′ and that, in the event of a strike, it expects “minimal impact to operations and a smooth move-in day.”

The university’s custodians are represented by a separate union that does not plan to strike, and the workers who man service kiosks in building lobbies are not represented by the union, either.

The housing workers are unionized under the banner of the Service Employees International Union, which also represents USC’s shuttle drivers. In May, those drivers threatened to strike during the university’s commencement ceremony — then aborted after reaching an eleventh-hour agreement with USC.

Six months prior, unionized graduate students also threatened to strike before reaching a tentative agreement just before fall semester finals.

“USC must get serious at the bargaining table soon,” Moreno said in the press release. “If not, we’re ready to strike.”
